zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content: Hi! I am Jaan. I am teaching this course and through the data thinking principles we will learn together I hope to help people feel more self-efficacy and agency in an era where much of the forces that shape our behavior, information consumption, political decisions, financial decisions and resources are hidden in closed-source artificial intelligence technology.
zerver_message.rendered_content: Hi! I am Jaan. I am teaching this course and through the data thinking principles we will learn together I hope to help people feel more self-efficacy and agency in an era where much of the forces that shape our behavior, information consumption, political decisions, financial decisions and resources are hidden in closed-source artificial intelligence technology.

zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content:
Hello Jaan,
I am Nesma, a Ph.D. student at the University of Tartu.
I understood from the description in OIS that the course will not focus on specific methods, but the idea is to put them all together. So I look forward to acquiring hands-on experience solving real-world problems with appropriate data analysis methods and learning about the best practices for designing effective solutions. Additionally, I look forward to gaining data visualization and storytelling skills, enabling me to communicate data findings more effectively to stakeholders. Furthermore, exploring emerging trends and innovations in the field of data science as the ChatGPT :).

is the following easier to understand?

objectives:
```quote
The objective of the course is to teach the fundamental
concepts in data science, artificial intelligence, natural language
processing, and causal inference in the service of data analysis,
visualization, communication, and decision-making based on
inferences. This course will empower you to take on the world
using these powerful tools.
```

learning outcomes: 
```quote
● You will create and publish a report using the help of
ChatGPT for the data thinking course blog related to a
dataset you need to use to make a decision about your
life; you will defend this report through a presentation.
● The report you create will demonstrate your ability to
apply the principles of data thinking, such as identifying
research questions and testing your hypotheses
regarding the data you have collected, cleaned,
analyzed, and visualized.
● The interactive component of the report will include a
deployed machine learning model that helps someone
make a decision based on the data thinking principles
you select as most helpful.
● You will critique, defend, appraise the use of data
thinking in domains such as economics, health care, life
sciences, pharmaceuticals, climate change, real estate,
finance, and science.
● You will find, analyze, and report your findings on
public datasets or datasets you collect, curate, or create.
● You will use version control systems such as Git and
GitHub, Data Version Control, Google Colaboratory
Notebooks, Jupyter Notebooks, LaTeX, Visual Studio
Code, Copilot, ChatGPT.
● You will differentiate between appropriate methods and
the pros and cons of using each depending on the scale,
level of structure, source, and issues in specific datasets
both large and small.
● You will describe and define key terms and concepts
related to the principles of data thinking, machine
learning and artificial intelligence, statistics, causal
inference, natural language processing, and large
language models.
● You will review your classmate’s code and provide
constructive feedback on code style, code quality, and
best practices in the principles of data thinking.
● You will classify, discuss, summarize, and explain key
concepts of data thinking
```

let me know if that helps and i will revise it accordingly!

zerver_message.content:
@_**Kaarel Kaarelson|591047** [said](https://datathinking.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/345278-general/topic/main/near/329296225):
```quote
1) I'm taking a course called [Artificial Intelligence](https://ois2.ut.ee/#/courses/LTAT.01.003/version/67a5a324-87cc-c40e-7cd5-80b05ab18d0f/details), how does this course differ from it? Are we using ChatGPT just as an add-on?
```
great question! it looks like that course is in estonian, and this data thinking course is in english. 

it is unfortunate -- because my mother tongue is estonian -- but the fact is that many terms in computer science and machine learning are difficult to translate. for example, chatGPT, deep learning, AI, etc, so i find computer science research in estonian more confusing than in english where these words originate, especially for newer research. 

for example when i gave a talk at north star AI (a conference in tallinn) a few years ago, i tried to introduce these concepts in estonian: masinõppe ja tehisintellekt pilves, võrgustikku trenn graafiku töötelmismasinatega, jne. 

so i think the best approach may be to decide what languages you hope to work in, read research papers in, etc. 

the topics are probably the same, but broader coverage or emphasis of reinforcement learning or computer vision seems likely for LTAT.01.003 versus data thinking. i hope to go more in-depth on ethics in AI (e.g. people in kenya getting paid little money to train ChatGPT), and also teach the underlying statistics, mathematics, and programming needed to build chatGPT yourself. 

does that help? let me know if you have any remaining questions!

zerver_message.content:
@_**Kaarel Kaarelson|591047** [said](https://datathinking.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/345278-general/topic/main/near/329296225):
```quote
2) Why is the objective to publish the final reports to One Fact Foundation website, the non-profit you're co-founder of? Why not publish it to Medium or Towards Data Science blog?
```
this is because of legal and technical reasons. 

legally, the course is creative commons with recordings livestreamed on https://www.twitch.tv/onefactfoundation (not the zoom call, only my audio and video; by law, no student faces can be shown and the twitch interface through an app called OBS can't even access the zoom app; setup is here: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org/issues/16). 

this is because my salary is paid by the university of pennsylvania and by university of tartu, and one way to work across institutions in this manner that cannot hire me full-time as a tenured professor is to share resources. 

further, to ensure that other students benefit and the course improves over time, the content is creative commons licensed (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/legalcode) and software is apache 2.0 licensed (https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0). 

this ensures that the most people around the world who can't afford education, chatgpt, or other such tools can still get access to the material.

similarly, there is a paywall at towards data science and medium, which prevents people from reading it if they can't afford subscriptions or do not want their data harvested by these privately-run, for-profit companies. 

however, students are free to publish anywhere -- the creative commons means content can be adapted and re-used for any purpose! :) 

another technical reason is that tools like `altair`, `latex`, `duckdb`, `apache arrow`, and others are supported by next.js (how we build the website, https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org/), which means students can benefit from learning to use these tools and processes. but a tool like medium or towards data science prohibits use of these things which makes it quite complicated to publish interactive data analyses and data thinking processess

hope this helps! let me know if you have any remaining questions about this -- excellent questions, and you are doing the data thinking, data detective process already!

zerver_message.content:
[img.png](/user_uploads/47304/FPXoM0fTZl4BWtWe3dCS6E4K/img.png)

**Data is random** 

**code is here look for raw text ** 

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Define the sales data as a numpy array
sales_data = np.array([[1000, 800, 1200, 1500, 2000, 2500, 3000, 3500, 3000, 2500, 2000, 1500]])

# Add a row of random losses from fraud using the numpy random function
fraud_losses = np.random.randint(0, 1000, (1, 12))
sales_data = np.append(sales_data, fraud_losses, axis=0)

# Define the x-axis labels as the months
months = ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun', 'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec']

# Create a line plot with the sales data and fraud losses
plt.plot(months, sales_data[0], label='Sales')
plt.plot(months, sales_data[1], label='Losses from Fraud')

# Set the plot title, labels, and legend
plt.title('Sales Data with Fraud Losses')
plt.xlabel('Months')
plt.ylabel('Dollars')
plt.legend()

# Show the plot
plt.show()

zerver_message.subject: intros
zerver_message.content:
Heya everyone! Sorry for the late reply.
I'm a Data Science masters student at Tartu University.

I'm kind of in-between about declaring this course or not.
I'm doing and defending  my thesis this semester and I just had a child few days ago. I'm also working full time as a Data engineer with various health data at a governmental IT-house. Hence I have this question: Can I do this course just for myself without having to declare anything? I do not want to be at point later where I just do not have the time to do the required project/exam and I get not passed on my final marks.

Besides that I'm very interested about how I could utilize chatgpt effectively at various aspects of my life, for example:
1) as a Data engineer, data scientist 
2) with my masters thesis
3) anything I want to research and learn about

How to systematically utilize chatgpt for Maximum benefit? By that I do not mean to get a copy-paste answers to ones questions, but to actually learn from the answers. 
-Is there a kind of blueprint one could follow when working with chatgpt? How would that look like?
-no technology is perfect. What are chatgpts shortcomings we should be aware of?
- chatgpt is gonna change the world alot! Theres probably going to be a myriad of so called "experts" who  actually know nothing about the subject wouldn't it be for the help of chatgpt. How should we handle this kind of world?
I could go on but I'm gonna draw a line here.

I appreciate the initiative alot and find it to be a very crucial course, hence also why I find it so important to do it at my own pace.
BR!
Rasmus

I did this by first copying the path of my data file (by clicking on the file name and then right click) then I asked ChatGPT what to do next. It said I should use command **"cd"** and the name of the file path I have just copied, so for me it was the code - cd /workspaces/datathinking.org-codespace/data/
Then I had to write the code - ls Minerals_Database.csv using the command **"ls"** so make sure that the file exists and then I plotted the code you and ChatGPT gave me - 
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data from CSV file
df = pd.read_csv('Minerals_Database.csv')

# Extract relevant columns
mohs_hardness = df['Mohs Hardness']
specific_gravity = df['Specific Gravity']

# Create scatter plot
plt.scatter(specific_gravity, mohs_hardness)
plt.xlabel('Specific Gravity')
plt.ylabel('Mohs Hardness')
plt.title('Mohs Hardness vs Specific Gravity')

# Show plot
plt.show()

zerver_message.content:
Hello. My name is Tim. I am an ethnographer - I study humans and their in their natural habitats -   and I am a designer - I make the plans and specifications for the building of things (and non-things) ... a lot of 'non-things' in recent years, as I have been working with service/experience and other strategic and holistic design approaches. I started out as a graphic designer and printer/setter (photo-mechanical) and over the years worked in interaction design, animation, advertising, digital, and ... I love bicycles and sushi. I am a polyglot.   I'm learning to oil paint. My favourite number is 42. A good book I like is: THHGTTG.  

Very happy to be part of this course! I look forward to learning some of the maths behind all this AL/ML stuff!

Hello everyone,

I recently analyzed the IMDb Movies Dataset (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/rajugc/imdb-movies-dataset-based-on-genre) and focused specifically on action movies. With the help of ChatGPT, I generated an interactive plot that displays the relationship between Movie Rating and Gross Box Office.

However, due to missing data for some movies in the dataset, the Gross Box Office data may not be very reliable. Nonetheless, the plot still provides an interesting and engaging visualization: [Figure_1-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/KH2uA9TUEwMNvrdncatDbOHK/Figure_1-gpt.png) [Figure_2-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/WaGz0O68BtSuZCNX05UoaPyS/Figure_2-gpt.png) [Figure_3-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/NLbNo_z-KsFueJo_nm2xZhN3/Figure_3-gpt.png) [Figure_4-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/_XSnr6cQI4mAv9M5zMA5jhRT/Figure_4-gpt.png)

hi @**everyone** ! just emailed everyone the link to the latest lecture recording. 

the example we did in class for the plan to do logistic regression is in the example data thinking codespace: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org-codespace/blob/main/notebooks/230227-logistic-regression-example-on-iris-dataset.ipynb 

please let me know if you didn't get the email or have any questions! it is exciting to get to co-create this material, so please continue asking when you are stuck and sharing resources in the chat as you are doing. 

the visualizations you are already making are awesome!!! and the experience reports!!!! 

for context, it took me many years to learn these skills and i have not taken a formal computer science class. so if it's hard for you, it was very hard for me and it's normal to ask for a lot of help or need a lot of guidance from humans or ChatGPT. 

here's a helpful link for describing the unix shell (https://missing.csail.mit.edu/2020/course-shell/) which will help with codespaces and stuff. 

see you soon!

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
I used my own data (bacterial composition of human gut for 2400 people from Estonian population). 
[plot.png](/user_uploads/47304/WUTICPghlJCXs5kgwcX0FMkB/plot.png) 

First I wrote the code myself and then I asked chatGTP to improve my code. Here is the suggestions and my comments:

1. Instead of assigning the colors to a list, you can use the built-in color maps in Matplotlib, such as 'tab10', 'tab20', or 'Pastel1'. This can simplify your code and ensure better color contrast.
- I disagree, I did it on purpose because I don't like standard palettes.
 
2. You are reassigning the plt variable, which is not recommended as it overwrites the default plt module. Instead, you can use a different variable name, such as ax.
- Okay, maybe that's better.

3. Since you're importing pyplot twice, it's better to just import it once at the beginning of your code.
- It's true, I didn't notice it.
[code1.png](/user_uploads/47304/oPU4UeT5v0_9m5_VcMUHjkPS/code1.png)

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Define some usage statistics for electric cars with Li-ion batteries
car_names = ['Tesla Model S', 'Nissan Leaf', 'Chevrolet Bolt', 'BMW i3', 'Ford Mustang Mach-E']
car_sales = [80000, 140000, 50000, 30000, 25000]
car_ranges = [400, 150, 259, 153, 270]

# Create a bar chart of car sales
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.bar(car_names, car_sales)
ax.set_ylabel('Sales')
ax.set_title('Usage Statistics of Electric Cars with Li-ion Batteries')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Create a line chart of car ranges
fig2, ax2 = plt.subplots()
ax2.plot(car_names, car_ranges, marker='o')
ax2.set_ylabel('Range (miles)')
ax2.set_title('Usage Statistics of Electric Cars with Li-ion Batteries')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

plt.show()

hi all! if you're curious, here is where i got stuck after class. i had to email github's support team for help. (sharing because i think it helps to align on style guide and best practices, such as the reading in the intro class)

Hi! I'm teaching datathinking.org, an open source course at several schools. There are over 100 students and this is a severe blocker (I might be naïve and missing something basic here!).

I teach using github codespaces, and it is AMAZING (thank you!).

However, I can't commit to this repository: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org-codespace

What I do right now:
- use a personal account to teach in class (https://github.com/altosaar/datathinking.org-codespace)
- use the below code to transfer changes from this code to the main data thinking codespace

Is there a better way? 

Grateful for any help! Thank you so, so much for making this -- the students are not dependent on Colab (which is harder to afford GPUs on in Estonia, and other non-Western contexts the course is aimed at).

Jaan

hi all! if you're curious, here is where i got stuck after class. i had to email github's support team for help. (sharing because i think it helps to align on style guide and best practices, such as the reading in the intro class)

Hi! I'm teaching datathinking.org, an open source course at several schools. There are over 100 students and this is a severe blocker (I might be naïve and missing something basic here!).

I teach using github codespaces, and it is AMAZING (thank you!).

However, I can't commit to this repository: https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org-codespace

What I do right now:

  • use a personal account to teach in class (https://github.com/altosaar/datathinking.org-codespace)
  • use the below code to transfer changes from this code to the main data thinking codespace

Is there a better way?

Grateful for any help! Thank you so, so much for making this -- the students are not dependent on Colab (which is harder to afford GPUs on in Estonia, and other non-Western contexts the course is aimed at).

Jaan

hi all! i'm finally completing the [homework](https://github.com/onefact/datathinking.org/issues/9) :) 

i have some experience with data thinking through teaching this course where we are defining what it is together, and i have done some research in machine learning and artificial intelligence through my graduate school training in computer science & computational physics. through this course i hope to articulate a theory of change for how society will be impacted by technology such as chatgpt, and how we can help learners around the world feel more agency and an internal locus of control when coping with large shifts in behavior, misinformation, and algorithmic advertising and recommender systems at societal & global scale.

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
I plot the dependence of the cost of living on the quality of life in different countries. Color marked parts of the world. The graph is interactive, if you move the cursor to the dot, you can see the name of the country.

Quality of Life Index (higher is better) is an estimation of overall quality of life by using an empirical formula which takes into account purchasing power index (higher is better), pollution index (lower is better), house price to income ratio (lower is better), cost of living index (lower is better), safety index (higher is better), health care index (higher is better), traffic commute time index (lower is better) and climate index (higher is better).
These indices are relative to New York City (NYC). Which means that for New York City, each index should be 100(%). If a city has a Cost of Living Index of 120, it means Numbeo has estimated it is 20% more expensive than New York (excluding rent).
data source: https://www.numbeo.com/cost-of-living/

Interactive plot here:
[Cost_vs_quality.html](/user_uploads/47304/0qoO4dslFQkerwzQENRmbwv-/Cost_vs_quality.html)

[Plot_printScreen.png](/user_uploads/47304/XnazT-nor5IrpSizuk3S9nZx/Plot_printScreen.png)

zerver_message.content:
@_**Nikolai Shurakov|590111** [said](https://datathinking.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/345278-general/topic/plotting/near/338295123):
```quote
Hello everyone,

I recently analyzed the IMDb Movies Dataset (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/rajugc/imdb-movies-dataset-based-on-genre) and focused specifically on action movies. With the help of ChatGPT, I generated an interactive plot that displays the relationship between Movie Rating and Gross Box Office.

However, due to missing data for some movies in the dataset, the Gross Box Office data may not be very reliable. Nonetheless, the plot still provides an interesting and engaging visualization: [Figure_1-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/KH2uA9TUEwMNvrdncatDbOHK/Figure_1-gpt.png) [Figure_2-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/WaGz0O68BtSuZCNX05UoaPyS/Figure_2-gpt.png) [Figure_3-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/NLbNo_z-KsFueJo_nm2xZhN3/Figure_3-gpt.png) [Figure_4-gpt.png](/user_uploads/47304/_XSnr6cQI4mAv9M5zMA5jhRT/Figure_4-gpt.png)
```
I tried to apply the regression model to the plot I made earlier. I am trying to understand the relationship between the rating of an action film, which is an indicator of its quality (let's assume so), and the gross box office, which is a measure of the total amount of money earned by the film. Based on this analysis, **there is not a strong relationship between these two variables**. The accuracy of the regression model is 37%.

This means that a film's box office success is not necessarily a strong indicator of its quality. It's possible for a movie to do well at the box office even if it's not highly rated by critics or audiences. Similarly, a movie that is highly rated may not necessarily be a box office hit.

It's important to note that correlation does not necessarily imply causation. Just because there is not a strong correlation between a movie's rating and its box office performance, it doesn't mean that one doesn't affect the other in some way. Other factors, such as marketing, budget, and star power, may also play a role in a movie's box office success. [image.png](/user_uploads/47304/57O5TUs1FACd1jXoxH-jZqjl/image.png)

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
My first plot was about Covid vaccination in different countries, however, the data I had was not good for applying linear regression to it (you can see screenshot 1). I decided to take a different dataset and chose this one (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/uciml/red-wine-quality-cortez-et-al-2009), which gives information about wine quality. Things went significantly better, however, the accuracy was about 33% (screenshot 2). I asked chatgpt how I can improve it, and it suggested trying regression (screenshot 3) and feature engineering (screenshot 4). The last approach turned out to be the best and the accuracy was about 64% (twice bigger than in the beginning  ). I think I could make it even higher but I was afraid of overfitting so I decided to leave like that.
[dt_hw2_screenshot1.png](/user_uploads/47304/f5u0ENhHBgixFTIyVtB5bo5N/dt_hw2_screenshot1.png) [dt_hw2_screenshot2.png](/user_uploads/47304/XLkd87j096cGyakNUm2mAeI-/dt_hw2_screenshot2.png) [dt_hw2_screenshot3.png](/user_uploads/47304/hdAX6CxWo49uewFjdgaH0Kv1/dt_hw2_screenshot3.png) [dt_hw2_screenshot4.png](/user_uploads/47304/rodFjs2npj4EwR4djOJiPzkz/dt_hw2_screenshot4.png)
zerver_message.rendered_content:
My first plot was about Covid vaccination in different countries, however, the data I had was not good for applying linear regression to it (you can see screenshot 1). I decided to take a different dataset and chose this one (https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/uciml/red-wine-quality-cortez-et-al-2009), which gives information about wine quality. Things went significantly better, however, the accuracy was about 33% (screenshot 2). I asked chatgpt how I can improve it, and it suggested trying regression (screenshot 3) and feature engineering (screenshot 4). The last approach turned out to be the best and the accuracy was about 64% (twice bigger than in the beginning ). I think I could make it even higher but I was afraid of overfitting so I decided to leave like that.

```quote
Hi. Can you (@**Jaan Altosaar** )  pls, explain me how to add CSV file to repository and later to check if it is there? I asked ChatGPT it gave me  code below and I wrote to commit message. now it seems it accepted but I am not sure. 
git add <file_name>
git commit -m "Add <file_name> to repository"
git push

So I wanna check file list in repository. I asked ChatGPT how to find this: git ls-files

But there is no command found like this when I press Crtl+Shift+P together. nothing like such command when I search for it.

AND my main problem rn is related to have CSV file that I create to have in repos. as well. Because when attempting to plot it gives me same error every time that check if csv file is in repos.

IF POSSIBLE, COULD YOU PLS, ADDRESS THIS PROBLEM IN TODAY`S SESSION, I have dentist's app. at lecture time, so, I can watch the recording later today. Thanks.
```
@**everyone** // just wanted to call in @**Gulnara Yusibova|589761** for doing an AMAZING job advocating for herself, asking for help, and following the data thinking principles. she is *asking* for help, *doing* a lot to try to solve the problem she is experiencing, and *thinking* about it.

zerver_message.subject: plotting
zerver_message.content:
Hi, cutting it close this time with the homework :sweat_smile: 

Initially, I tried linear regression with the first homework dataset, but I had my doubts about it as there were only 9 data points. As expected, a linear regression model wasn't accurate, as the data itself was not linearly dependent. ChatGPT suggested trying polynomial regression, so I tried it on the dataset as well. It gave better results, but still, the model wouldn't be that useful in predicting the kind of data I was working on (Apple's total current assets across the years). [image.png](/user_uploads/47304/jiMauaBiDvQ6_k405nXwZnyd/image.png)  

After that, I downloaded a dataset of weather temperatures during WW2 from Kaggle and tried to predict the maximum temperature of the day based on the minimum temperature. As the dependency itself was more linear, and there was a lot more data, the predictions from the linear regression model were a lot better :) [image.png](/user_uploads/47304/-stmWB3T4Yd8JTiM5aJzYPwg/image.png)
